timeline.name: Field laptop imaged
timeline.description: Responder performed a live triage image before seizing the device. This anchors the start of the lab chain of custody.
timeline.insight: Baseline point for correlating later Autopsy findings with the original acquisition log.

timeline.name: Removable USB mounted
timeline.description: System log shows a removable drive labelled FIELD-USB was mounted while the laptop was still with the subject.
timeline.insight: Highlights potential staging media used to move tooling or exfiltrated data.

timeline.name: resume.docx modified
timeline.description: User account 'casey' saved a new version of resume.docx shortly after the USB activity.
timeline.insight: Cross-reference with keyword hits for 'macro' to illustrate hunting for persistence mechanisms in office files.

timeline.name: run.exe executed
timeline.description: Prefetch artifacts show run.exe launched from the removable drive path.
timeline.insight: Pairs with hash-set lookups to demonstrate whitelisting vs. suspicious binaries.

timeline.name: System log rotation
timeline.description: The Windows System log rotated immediately after run.exe executed, implying tampering or heavy activity.
timeline.insight: Useful talking point for retention strategies and why investigators export EVTX early.

hashSets.name: Known Good Reference
hashSets.description: Synthetic SHA-256 values generated for this portfolio build to show how Autopsy cross-references clean system files.
hashSets.source: Created for the Kali Linux Portfolio Autopsy simulator, derived from demo text blobs shipped in /public/demo-data/autopsy.

entries.label: notes.txt
entries.explanation: Matches the base64 demo note bundled with the simulator; used to teach hash verification workflows.

hashSets.name: Investigator Watchlist
hashSets.description: Fictional suspicious binaries crafted for classroom walk-throughs. They are inert placeholders and safe to share.
hashSets.source: Randomized using OpenSSL locally while preparing this fixture; no real malware samples are referenced.

entries.label: run.exe
entries.explanation: Represents the executable discussed in the timeline. Instructors can show how to pivot from a hash hit to execution evidence.

entries.label: macro-enabled template
entries.explanation: Demonstrates why office document macros should be validated before trusting a resume or template file.
